I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) for Improving Market Linkages for 
Cottage and Small Industries (CSIs) will help Bhutan develop the capacity of CSIs to gain 
exposure and profitably operate in domestic and international markets.1 The TA will support the 
Government of Bhutan in streamlining standardization and certification, while implementing an 
integrated market access program to promote select CSI products. 
 
2.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  three  operational  priorities  of  Strategy  2030  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB): addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, accelerating 
progress in gender equality, and fostering regional cooperation and integration.  The TA is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2020–2022 for Bhutan.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Bhutan is one of the smallest but fastest-growing economies, with an annual average 
economic growth rate of 7% since the late 1980s.3 Despite high growth rates, Bhutan has faced 
a persistent development challenge: the economy remains relatively undiversified and heavily 
reliant on hydropower exports. CSIs account for 95% of all industries and employ an estimated 
99,228  people.4  CSIs  are  significant  because  of  their  potential  for  growth  and  economic 
diversification.5 While CSIs are promising sources of employment and broad-based economic 
growth, they face a number of challenges. 
 
4.  Although CSIs are crucial to drive Bhutan’s economic growth, they are prevented from 
realizing their full potential by a poor entrepreneurship culture, limited access to finance and 
effective business development services, and weak market linkages. To gain exposure and 
sustained market access in higher-value domestic and international markets, a multipronged 
approach is required to support CSIs in certification and market access. 
 
5.  The Department of Cottage and Small Industry (DCSI), Bhutan Agriculture and Food 
Regulatory Authority (BAFRA), Department of Trade, and Bhutan Standards Bureau (BSB) are 
mandated to support CSI product standardization and certification. However, a proper institutional 
network and coordination among these agencies are lacking. Fragmented strategy formulation 
and weak communication and coordination among agencies impede establishing a harmonized 
framework to standardize and certify products and set up a single-window service delivery 
system. 
 
6.  CSI products from Bhutan are not competitive in regional and international markets 
because  of  the  country’s  inability  to  utilize  economies  of  scale,  high  transport  costs,  and 
underdeveloped logistics sector. These challenges translate into higher prices for CSI products, 
making them uncompetitive. To capitalize on the unique features of CSI products certified under 
 
1  Cottage industries are those with investment of less than Nu1 million ($14,000 equivalent) and engaging up to four 
people. Small industries are those engaging 5–19 employees, with an investment of Nu1 million–Nu10 million 
($14,000–$140,000 equivalent). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 September 2019. 
3  Government of Bhutan. National Statistics Bureau. National Accounts Statistics from year 1988–2018. Thimphu. 
Average real gross domestic product growth was calculated from fiscal year (FY) 1988 to FY2018. 
4  Government of Bhutan. Ministry of Economic Affairs. 2019. Annual Report (2018–2019), Department of Cottage and 
Small Industry. Thimphu. 
5  Government of Bhutan. Ministry of Economic Affairs. 2019. Cottage and Small Industry and Start Up Development 
Program Blueprint. Thimphu.

2 
Brand Bhutan, CSIs must leverage the brand to gain exposure first and then sustained access to 
regional and international markets.6 
 
7.  Packaging and labeling are important in influencing consumer choices and decisions. 
While proper packaging ensures the product’s integrity and quality, consumers rely on information 
on the label to understand the product’s quality and value attributes. CSIs do not yet appreciate 
the value of proper packaging and labeling and must learn to use better packaging methods to 
meet Brand Bhutan standards and boost access to regional and international markets. 
 
8.  The government recognizes that a strong CSI base can become the bedrock of economic 
development. Recognizing the importance of CSIs, the government approved a Nu1.2 billion 
flagship program ($16 million equivalent) for CSI development in the 12th Five Year Plan.  The 
program aims to promote high-growth-potential CSIs to enable them to create a competitive niche 
in regional and international markets, and to mainstream CSIs into the economy (footnote 5). To 
help the government achieve the program’s intended results, all possible support must be 
leveraged to consolidate these results and fill in the missing links. 
 
9.  In 2007, ADB supported the CSI sector through the Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized 
Enterprise  Development  Program,  which  carried  out  policy  reforms,  stimulated  credit,  and 
supported business development services.7 The TA provides continuity and reflects lessons from 
projects  supported  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction—Advancing  Economic 
Opportunities for Women and Girls and Decentralized Coordination and Partnerships for Gender 
Equality Results—in terms of (i) concerted efforts from agencies mandated to improve market 
linkages for self-help groups’ products; and (ii) emphasis on product design, packaging, and 
labeling to gain access to higher-value markets.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: increased contribution of CSIs to gross 
domestic product and employment (footnote 4).9 The TA will have the following outcome: CSIs’ 
access to higher-value domestic and international market improved.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: National framework for CSI product standardization and certification 
established.  To  achieve  this  output,  a  participatory  baseline  assessment  of  institutional 
capacities will be conducted to establish a national product certification system and to provide 
certification services from a single window. Based on the assessment, the TA will (i) support the 
 
6  Brand Bhutan is a certification process under the Department of Trade, Ministry of Economic Affairs for products that 
reflect the values of Bhutan’s society and history and the Gross National Happiness philosophy.  
7  ADB. 2007. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to the Kingdom 
of Bhutan for the Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Program. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2013. Completion Report: Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Program in Bhutan. 
Manila; ADB. 2015. Implementation Completion Memorandum: Advancing Economic Opportunities for Women and 
Girls. Manila; ADB. 2019. Completion Report: Decentralized Coordination and Partnership for Gender Equality 
Results in Bhutan. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Enhancing 
Competitiveness of High-Value Agriculture and Artisan Products Value Chains. Manila. 
9  Government of Bhutan. Gross National Happiness Commission. 2018. 12th Five Year Plan: Cottage and Small 
Industry and Start Up Development Flagship Program. Thimphu. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
institutional strengthening of the DCSI and other government agencies, especially BAFRA and 
the BSB, to bring the quality of product certification in Bhutan up to par with regional and 
international standards;11 and (ii) design and implement national campaigns to promote the 
importance of product certification among CSIs and guide them through testing and certification.12 
Gender-sensitive efforts will ensure women entrepreneurs’ and related associations’ involvement 
in TA-supported activities, including all awareness, testing, and certification programs. 
 
12.  Output 2: CSI products promoted using Brand Bhutan. The DCSI intends to use Brand 
Bhutan to promote CSI products. The output comprises two components: 
 
(i)  Promote select domestic and export-oriented CSI products using “Made in 
Bhutan” and” Grown in Bhutan” labels of the Brand Bhutan strategy. For 
gender mainstreaming, the TA will focus on three types of products in which 
women’s  involvement  is  strong:  high-end  agricultural  products  (peanuts, 
dehydrated fruits, honey, and red rice); medicinal and aromatic plants (Sichuan 
pepper and caraway); and textiles and crafts (tourist souvenirs, including traditional 
paintings using natural pigments, home decor, scarves, and shawls). Agro-based 
products under the One Village One Product initiative supported by the Queen’s 
Project  Office,  and  products  with  strong  market  potential  under  the  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency’s Decentralized Hands-On Program Exhibition 
will also be promoted.13  
(ii)  Raise awareness of Brand Bhutan among CSI entrepreneurs and build their 
capacity to acquire certification. The TA will support targeted awareness and 
registration in countries offering the best opportunities for trade and e-trade. 
 
13.  Output  3:  Integrated  market  access  program  to  promote  select  CSI  products 
designed and implemented. The TA will support CSIs in accessing domestic, regional, and 
international markets by (i) establishing a market improvement center focusing on product design, 
packaging, and labeling; (ii) developing the capacity of 100 CSI start-ups and business owners in 
product packaging and labeling, including hand-holding support during one cycle of product 
placement.14 Priority will be given to products in output 2. To help develop the capacity of the 
DCSI, the TA will (i) train assigned DCSI officials (including economic development officers) in 
business  development  services  (e.g.,  business  mentoring,  marketing,  project  proposal 
preparation); and (ii) support the development of the DCSI’s online business development service 
portal. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,200,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of staff (including secretarial services as required), office 
accommodation  and  supplies,  furniture  and  utilities,  domestic  transport,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
 
11 Capacity development programs for the BSB will ensure that the agency can certify CSI products per the International 
Organization for Standardization (ISO) product certification system. 
12 The government will provide capital-intensive equipment facilities while the TA will provide simple equipment for CSI 
product testing and certification for training. 
13 The One Village One Product initiative was supported by ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan 
for Enhancing Competitiveness of High-Value Agriculture and Artisan Products Value Chains. Manila. 
14 The space and facilities for product packaging and labeling will be provided by the DCSI.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA and ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants. 
 
16.  The DCSI will be the TA executing agency. A small project management unit will be 
established within the DCSI to carry out day-to-day TA implementation. The Programming 
Division and Enterprise Development Division, in coordination with the project management unit, 
will work with the TA consultants to support two-way knowledge transfer though on-the-job 
training for DCSI staff members and the documenting of best practices in consulting reports, 
guidelines, and templates. The implementation arrangements are in the table.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,000,000 to the Government of Bhutan to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Improving Market Linkages for Cottage and Small Industries, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
